Detailed Description

Some useful locale related functions.

Explicit constructor using an LangType::language_t value to select locale.

Parameters:
lang The language used to select the locale.

LocaleUtility::LocaleUtility (  const char *  locale  )  [explicit]
 

Explicit constructor using a locale string to specify the locale.

Should only be used when std::locale is supported.

Parameters:
locale The locale as a string.

Member Function Documentation

bool LocaleUtility::collate (  const LocaleStringRef &  lhs,
const LocaleStringRef &  rhs
)  const [inline]
 

Decide whether one string should preceed another in a collation.

Both arguments accept char*, MC2String, and MC2String& by implicit conversion to LocaleStringRef.

Parameters:
lhs The first string.
rhs The second string.
Returns:
true if lhs should preceed rhs in the collation.

bool LocaleUtility::operator() (  const LocaleStringRef &  lhs,
const LocaleStringRef &  rhs
)  const [inline]
 

Calls collate with the same arguments.

This function makes it possible to use this object as a ordering functor in string containers.

Both arguments accept char*, MC2String, and MC2String& by implicit conversion to LocaleStringRef.

Parameters:
lhs The left hand argument.
rhs The right hand argument.
Returns:
lhs < rhs.

Definition at line 245 of file LocaleUtility.h.

const LocaleUtility& LocaleUtility::operator= (  const LocaleUtility &  o  ) 
 

Assignment constructor.

int LocaleUtility::strcmp (  const LocaleStringRef &  strA,
const LocaleStringRef &  strB
)  const
 

Compare two strings according to locale.

Works like the system call strcmp (this method currently only pass the call to the system).

Both arguments accept char*, MC2String, and MC2String& by implicit conversion to LocaleStringRef.

Parameters:
strA The first string to compare.
strB The second string to compare.
Returns:
An integer less than 0 if strA < strB, 0 if strA == strB and an integer > 0 if strA > strB.

Referenced by collate().

Member Data Documentation

struct __locale_struct* LocaleUtility::m_locale [private]
 

Pointer to GNU Extended locale object.

Normally we would use the __locale_t typedef, but this way we can treat include files better, we do not need to use the _USE_GNU define in this header file, only in the cpp-file.
